Afghanistan.notes: PLEASE_RESEARCH – fee schedule on consulate site not clearly stating a per-document legalization amount in USD

Algeria.notes: PLEASE_RESEARCH – embassy fee table does not show a single clear “legalization per document” line in USD

Bahrain.notes: Hague Convention member – U.S. documents are generally accepted in Bahrain with a Hague apostille; embassy legalization only occasionally requested for certain commercial cases.

Burkina Faso.notes: PLEASE_RESEARCH – consular fees vary by document type; no clear single legalization-per-document line

Burundi.notes: PLEASE_RESEARCH – consular fees vary by document type; no clear single legalization-per-document line

Cambodia.notes: Non‑Hague – U.S. documents must be authenticated (state + U.S. Department of State) and then legalized by the Royal Embassy of Cambodia in Washington, DC. Embassy internal fee schedule lists Authentication / Legalization at $100 per document; confirm in case of future changes.

Cameroon.notes: Non‑Hague – U.S. documents require state (and often U.S. Department of State) authentication, then legalization at the Embassy of Cameroon in Washington, DC. Embassy consular fee schedule lists an application fee of $2.72 per request plus $2.72 legalization fee per document; confirm current rates before each case.

Canada.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – Canadian documents for use abroad and foreign documents for use in Canada generally rely on apostilles rather than consular legalization. Global Affairs Canada and provincial authorities act as competent authorities for apostilles; routine apostille issuance itself carries no consular “legalization” fee like non‑Hague embassies charge.

Cape Verde.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – documents for use in Cabo Verde generally require an apostille, not consular legalization. Competent authorities for apostilles include the Direcção-Geral dos Registos e Notariado (Ministry of Justice) and the Direcção-Geral dos Assuntos Consulares e Comunidades (Ministry of Foreign Affairs).

Central African Republic.notes: Non‑Hague – Embassy site describes a multi‑step process (U.S. authentication, French translation, then CAR embassy legalization). Official page quotes an authentication fee of $30–$50 per document plus an optional $25 express surcharge; using $50 as the consular per‑document fee is a conservative estimate.

Chad.notes: PLEASE_RESEARCH – embassy site does not show a clear legalization fee table

Chile.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – Chile accepts apostilled documents instead of consular legalization; no consular legalization service offered in our workflow for Chile.

China.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – China recognizes apostilled foreign public documents in place of consular legalization, and Chinese authorities issue apostilles for Chinese documents via the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and designated local authorities. Consular legalization is no longer used between China and other Apostille countries.

Colombia.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – Colombian and foreign public documents for use between Colombia and other Hague members rely on apostilles issued by the Colombian Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Apostille and Legalizations Coordination) or by the competent authority of the issuing country, instead of consular legalization.

Comoros.notes: Hague status unclear from core HCCH tables; many third‑party services treat Comoros as accepting apostilles, but the HCCH status table does not yet list a clear entry into force. Treat as PLEASE_RESEARCH for now and confirm directly with the Comoros mission before accepting work.

Congo.notes: Non‑Hague – public documents for the Republic of the Congo (Congo‑Brazzaville) still follow the traditional chain: notarization (if applicable), state authentication, U.S. Department of State authentication, then consular legalization at the Republic of Congo embassy or consulate; no reliable, official per‑document consular fee table located online, so fees must be confirmed case‑by‑case. Non‑Hague – the Democratic Republic of the Congo is not a party to the Apostille Convention, so documents must be fully legalized through the DRC embassy or consulate; use 200 USD as the consular fee and 95 USD as your service fee baseline, confirming exact consular charges directly with the embassy for each case.

Cook Islands.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – the Convention entered into force for the Cook Islands on 30 April 2005, so documents normally require a single apostille rather than consular legalization, issued by the Cook Islands Ministry of Foreign Affairs and Immigration as the competent authority.

Costa Rica.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – the Convention entered into force for Costa Rica on 14 December 2011, so documents normally require a single apostille rather than consular legalization.

Croatia.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – the Convention entered into force for Croatia on 8 October 1993, so documents normally require a single apostille rather than consular legalization.

Cuba.notes: Non‑Hague – Cuba is not a party to the Apostille Convention, so U.S. documents must be authenticated and then fully legalized through the Cuban embassy or consulate; use 0 as the default consular fee placeholder and 95 as your service fee, confirming exact consular charges directly before quoting clients.

Cyprus.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – the Convention entered into force for Cyprus on 30 April 1973, so documents normally require only an apostille rather than consular legalization, issued by the designated Cypriot competent authorities.

Czech Republic.notes: Hague Convention - standard apostille Hague Apostille Convention – the Convention entered into force for the Czech Republic on 16 March 1999, so documents normally require only an apostille rather than consular legalization.

C\u00f4te d'Ivoire.notes: PLEASE_RESEARCH – embassy site does not publish a simple legalization fee per document in USD Hague Apostille Convention – the Convention entered into force for Côte d'Ivoire in 2012 (check exact date if you need it in the UI), so documents normally require an apostille instead of consular legalization.

Dominica.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – Dominica has accepted apostilles since 3 November 1978, so documents normally require only an apostille rather than consular legalization.

Dominican Republic.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – the Convention entered into force for the Dominican Republic on 30 July 2009, so documents normally require only an apostille rather than consular legalization.

Ecuador.notes: Hague Convention - standard apostille Hague Apostille Convention – the Convention entered into force for Ecuador on 2 April 2005, so documents normally require only an apostille rather than consular legalization.

Egypt.notes: PLEASE_RESEARCH – consulate and US‑Arab Chamber fees depend on document type; confirm from current schedules Non‑Hague – Egypt is not a party to the Apostille Convention, so documents must go through full consular legalization; use 128 USD as the typical per‑document Egyptian embassy fee for commercial or official documents, and 35 USD for the standard U.S. Arab Chamber of Commerce stamp when required, with 95 USD as your service fee baseline.

Eritrea.notes: Non‑Hague – Eritrea is not a party to the Apostille Convention, so documents must go through full embassy legalization; published breakdowns of typical packages show an Eritrea Embassy fee of about 50 USD per document, with your own service fee set at 95 USD and other U.S. government or courier charges added separately as needed.

Estonia.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – the Convention entered into force for Estonia on 30 September 2001, so documents normally require only an apostille rather than consular legalization.

Eswatini.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – Eswatini (formerly Swaziland) has been under the Apostille Convention since 6 September 1968, so documents normally require only an apostille rather than consular legalization.

Ethiopia.notes: Non‑Hague – Ethiopia is not a party to the Apostille Convention, so documents must be fully legalized through the Ethiopian Embassy; a commonly quoted embassy fee is about 95 USD per document, with 95 USD as a reasonable baseline for your own service fee, while U.S. state and federal authentication fees are added separately.

Fiji.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – Fiji has been under the Apostille Convention since 29 March 1971, so documents normally require only an apostille rather than consular legalization.

Finland.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – Finland has applied the Apostille Convention since 31 May 1965, so documents normally require only an apostille rather than consular legalization.

France.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – France has applied the Apostille Convention since 24 January 1965, so documents normally require only an apostille rather than consular legalization.

Gambia.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – The Gambia is a Hague country, so documents normally require an apostille instead of consular legalization.

Georgia.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – Georgia is a Hague country, so documents normally require only an apostille rather than consular legalization.

Germany.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – Germany is a Hague country, so documents normally require only an apostille rather than consular legalization.

Ghana.notes: Non‑Hague – Ghana is not a party to the Apostille Convention, so documents must be fully legalized through the Ghanaian Embassy or consulate; leave the consular fee at 0 for now and use 95 USD as your service fee baseline, confirming current embassy fees case‑by‑case.

Grenada.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – Grenada has accepted apostilles since 7 April 2002, so documents normally require only an apostille rather than consular legalization.

Guinea-Bissau.notes: Non‑Hague – Guinea‑Bissau is not a party to the Apostille Convention, so documents must be fully legalized through the Guinea‑Bissau Embassy or consulate; use 105 USD as a reasonable per‑document consular fee benchmark (mirroring regional embassy pricing) and 95 USD as your service fee baseline, with U.S. state and federal authentication fees added separately.

Guyana.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – the Convention entered into force for Guyana on 18 April 2019, so documents normally require only an apostille rather than consular legalization.

Haiti.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – Haiti is a Hague country (Convention in force since 13 January 2024), so documents normally require only an apostille rather than consular legalization.

Honduras.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – Honduras is a Hague country (Convention in force since 20 January 2004), so documents normally require only an apostille rather than consular legalization.

Hong Kong.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – Hong Kong has long been covered by the Apostille Convention (now via China), so U.S. documents for Hong Kong normally require only an apostille rather than consular legalization.

Hungary.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – the Convention entered into force for Hungary on 18 January 1973, so documents normally require only an apostille rather than consular legalization.

Iceland.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – Iceland has been a party to the Apostille Convention since 27 November 2004, so documents normally require only an apostille rather than consular legalization.

India.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – the Convention entered into force for India on 14 July 2005, so documents normally require only an apostille rather than consular legalization.

Indonesia.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – the Convention entered into force for Indonesia on 4 June 2022, so documents normally require only an apostille rather than consular legalization.

Iran.notes: Non‑Hague – Iran is not a party to the Apostille Convention, so documents must go through full embassy legalization; use 100 USD as a typical per‑document Iranian embassy fee benchmark and 95 USD as your service fee baseline, with U.S. state and federal authentication fees added separately.

Iraq.notes: Non‑Hague – Iraq is not a party to the Apostille Convention, so personal and civil documents must be fully legalized through the Iraqi Embassy or consulate; Iraqi consular fee schedules show general ratification of non‑commercial documents at about 15 USD per document, so use 15 as the consular fee and keep 95 USD as your service fee baseline, with U.S. state and federal authentication fees added separately. Non‑Hague – Iraq is not a party to the Apostille Convention, so commercial documents must be fully legalized through the Iraqi Embassy or commercial attaché; Iraqi consular schedules list ratification of commercial documents (commercial invoices, certificates of origin, etc.) at about 160 USD per document, so use 160 as the consular fee and keep 95 USD as your service fee baseline, with U.S. state and federal authentication fees added separately.

Ireland.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – the Convention entered into force for Ireland on 9 March 1999, so documents normally require only an apostille rather than consular legalization.

Israel.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – the Convention entered into force for Israel on 14 August 1978, so documents normally require only an apostille rather than consular legalization.

Italy.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – the Convention entered into force for Italy on 11 February 1978, so documents normally require only an apostille rather than consular legalization.

Jamaica.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – the Convention entered into force for Jamaica on 3 July 2021, so documents normally require only an apostille rather than consular legalization.

Japan.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – the Convention entered into force for Japan on 27 July 1970, so documents normally require only an apostille rather than consular legalization.

Jordan.notes: Non‑Hague – Jordan is not a party to the Apostille Convention, so personal and other civil documents must be fully legalized through the Jordanian Embassy or consulate; the embassy’s current fee tables show an Embassy of Jordan fee of 11.25 USD per personal document, so use 11.25 as the consular fee and keep 95 USD as your service fee baseline, with U.S. state and federal authentication fees added separately. Non‑Hague – company and other legal documents for Jordan (POAs, agreements, articles, certificates, etc.) must also be fully legalized; the embassy lists an Embassy of Jordan fee of 47.25 USD per document for these, so use 47.25 as the consular fee and keep 95 USD as your service fee baseline, with U.S. state and federal authentication fees added separately.

Kazakhstan.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – Kazakhstan has been a party to the Apostille Convention since 30 January 2001, so documents normally require only an apostille rather than consular legalization.

Kenya.notes: Non‑Hague – Kenya is not a party to the Apostille Convention, so documents must be fully legalized through the Kenyan Embassy or consulate; use 50 USD as a reasonable per‑document consular fee benchmark and 95 USD as your service fee baseline, with U.S. state and federal authentication fees added separately.

Kiribati.notes: Non‑Hague – Kiribati is not a party to the Apostille Convention, so documents must be fully legalized through the relevant embassy or consulate; use 50 USD as a reasonable per‑document consular fee benchmark and 95 USD as your service fee baseline, with U.S. state and federal authentication fees added separately.

Kuwait.notes: Non‑Hague – Kuwait is not a party to the Apostille Convention, so documents must be fully legalized through the Embassy of Kuwait or consulate; use 25 USD as a typical per‑document consular fee for personal/legal documents and keep 95 USD as your service‑fee baseline, with U.S. state and federal authentication fees added separately. Non‑Hague – commercial export documents for Kuwait (commercial invoices, certificates of origin, packing lists, etc.) usually carry higher consular charges; use 50 USD as your standard per‑document consular‑fee line for commercial export documents in your model (noting that some items may cost more) and keep 95 USD as your service‑fee baseline, plus any chamber‑of‑commerce and U.S. authentication charges.

Laos.notes: Non‑Hague – Laos is not a party to the Apostille Convention, so documents must be fully legalized through the Lao embassy or consulate; use 50 USD as a reasonable per‑document consular‑fee assumption and 95 USD as your service‑fee baseline, with U.S. state and federal authentication fees added separately.

Latvia.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – the Convention is in force for Latvia, so documents normally only need an apostille from the competent authority in the issuing country rather than full consular legalization; set the embassy consular‑fee field to 0 in your table and treat any rare, case‑specific embassy‑legalization charges as “TBD – confirm with mission if required.”

Lebanon.notes: Non‑Hague – Lebanon is not a party to the Apostille Convention, so documents must be fully legalized through the Lebanese embassy or consulate; use 40 USD as a typical consular fee for basic personal/legal documents in your model and 95 USD as your service‑fee baseline, with U.S. state and federal authentication fees added separately. Non‑Hague – commercial and corporate documents for Lebanon (invoices, certificates of origin, corporate registrations, etc.) usually incur higher consular fees; use 90 USD as your standard per‑document consular‑fee assumption for commercial items, recognizing that some company‑status or registration documents can be higher, and keep 95 USD as your service‑fee baseline plus any chamber‑of‑commerce and U.S. authentication charges.

Lesotho.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – Lesotho is a member of the Convention, so documents destined for Lesotho typically require only an apostille from the competent authority in the issuing country rather than full consular legalization; set the embassy consular‑fee field to 0 in your table and treat any rare embassy‑legalization need as “TBD – confirm with mission if required.”

Liberia.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – Liberia is a member of the Convention, so documents destined for Liberia usually only need an apostille from the competent authority in the issuing country instead of full consular legalization; set the embassy consular‑fee field to 0 and regard any exceptional embassy‑legalization request as “TBD – confirm with mission if required.”

Libya.notes: Non‑Hague – Libya is not a party to the Apostille Convention, so documents must be fully legalized through the Libyan embassy or consulate; use 100 USD as a standard per‑document consular fee for most non‑commercial civil, personal, and general legal documents, and keep 95 USD as your service‑fee baseline with U.S. state and federal authentication fees added separately. [web:976][web:977] Non‑Hague – commercial and corporate documents for Libya (commercial invoices, certificates of origin, corporate registrations, etc.) also require full embassy legalization; U.S. service schedules and official embassy notices commonly show about 100 USD per commercial or civil document, so use 100 USD as your commercial consular‑fee assumption and 95 USD as your service‑fee baseline, plus any chamber‑of‑commerce and U.S. authentication costs. [web:976][web:977][web:979]

Liechtenstein.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – Liechtenstein is a member, so documents going to Liechtenstein normally require only an apostille from the competent authority in the issuing country rather than full consular legalization; set the embassy consular‑fee field to 0 in your table and treat any rare super‑legalization via a Liechtenstein mission as “TBD – confirm with mission if required.” [web:981][web:984][web:990]

Lithuania.notes: Hague Apostille Convention – Lithuania is a member, so documents destined for Lithuania generally need only an apostille from the competent authority in the issuing country instead of full consular legalization; set the embassy consular‑fee field to 0, and consider any exceptional consular‑legalization requirement as “TBD – confirm with mission,” while remembering that Lithuania may still legalize documents from non‑Hague states through its embassies and consulates. Madagascar.notes: Non‑Hague – Madagascar is not a party to the Apostille Convention, so documents must be fully legalized through the Madagascar embassy or consulate; use 1 USD as the nominal per‑document consular‑fee benchmark (since the direct embassy charge is very low) and keep 95 USD as your service‑fee baseline, with U.S. state and federal authentication fees added separately.
